intro: Solanum nigrum subsp. miniatum, commonly known as the small black nightshade, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to southern Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the nightshade family, Solanaceae, and is characterized by its small, dark purple to black berries that mature in the autumn. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm, with hairy stems and alternate, ovate leaves. Its flowers are small, yellowish, and clustered in umbels, and it thrives in disturbed soils and sunny habitats. The berries are toxic when unripe but can be used in traditional medicine in some regions.
